response.answer_text: I discuss this at length on my blog. Revenge of the spies. How to become a target for the CIA, MI6, FSB and Mossad all at once. I have extracted the portion dealing with the origins of Novichoks here. As Iran produced Novichoks in 2016, it seems likely that 20 or 30 countries could make them.  Mirzayanov, who did not work in the lab itself, says that only the most sophisticated countries could make Novichoks. This list would be the US, the UK, France and Russia. Actually, in 2016, Iran declared that it had made five members of the Novichoks family. If Iran can make Novichoks there are probably at least 20-30 other countries with the capability. Iran gave the spectral data to analyse the agents to the OPCW. The OPCW is therefore very well-placed to analyze the British samples. Novichoks are apparently not difficult to make in principle. Two relatively innocuous agrochemical precursors can be carried by an individual. Creating deadly Novichok is apparently just an issue of mixing together. How this produces a powder at first pass is beyond me. However, before being put into weapon it must be made and tested. The big problem is to avoid killing yourself after mixing the precursors. The huge investments at government run CBW sites Include enormous levels of protection against accidental exposure. A sufficiently desperate mafia chemist might decide to work with a fume cupboard, a Hazmat suit and a sealed room with a shower outside dispensing detergent based shampoo. After all, household detergent could neutralise traces left behind, particularly in the case of a fast decaying agent. There are two claims about potential Soviet sources. Mirzayanov says that the material was made in Nukus, a facility in Uzbekistan. The precursors came from a pesticide factory in Kazakhstan. US inspectors pulled down the Uzbekistan facility in 1999, somewhat late, considering that the Soviet Union fell in 1991. If the material had any shelf life, it could have been a leftover from Nukus. Another option for Russian production is Shikhany near Saratov where my office is based. This is a more serious option as a source. Saratov was a closed city, precisely because of the presence of this facility and the nearby Engels Air Force Base for long-range bombers. Without samples of the Russian Novichoks, it is impossible to say that the poison came from Russia. It can be done by looking for impurities in Russian samples, if they exist, they might correspond to a samplw of known Russian origin. It can be done less reliably by looking for matching impurities in the precursors. It could just possibly be done by looking at the ratios of phosphorus isotopes in the compound. This could indicate the general area in which the phosphates were mined. Unfortunately Russia is one of the biggest exporters of phosphates in the world so Russian phosphates could be anywhere. The only useful conclusion would be their absence proving that they didn't come from Russia.

They don’t, but only two laboratories are known to have ever produced, the one south of Moscow, Russia, and one in Iran in 2016, which provided us with the spectral data we can use to detect and identify the agents. However you need more than the means to obtain a suspect in an attempted murder case, you need three factors: means, opportunity and motive. There are two actors who had the means: Russia and Iran. Of those only Russia ever had a motive to kill the man, we can discount Iranian agent being behind the poisoning as lacking a motive and we’re only left with Russia as a result. However the question is about where the poison was manufactured, which is a conjecture that follows from this point. It might be that Iran provided the poison to Russia, but this seems needlessly complicated. Why would Russia use Iranian poison if they can make their own? Therefore the poison originated in Russia, in all likelyhood. MI6 can probably tell who brought it in and when, but disclosing that to the general public would threaten to expose their agents in Russia and you’ve just witnessed how they treat those.

They do not. Or at least, if they do, they aren’t explicitly stating it. The British “ultimatum” demanded that the Russian government explain how a nerve agent that was only ever produced in Russia (it was actually Uzbekistan but don’t worry about it) ended up in Britain. They can, however, reasonably assume that it was produced in Russia or the USSR. How it got outside of Russia is anybody’s guess, especially given that Russia had supposedly destroyed its last stores of chemical weapons. Whether it is therefore reasonable to assume that the Russian government would have any idea what Novichok was doing outside Russia is up for debate. There are just two sites where Novichok-5 has been produced: 1: State Scientific Institute of Organic Chemistry and Technology [known under its Russian acronym GONIIOKHT] at Shikhany, a closed military town near Saratov on the Volga.  2: The Soviet Chemical Research Institute, Nukus, Karakalpakstan This was closed down in 1992, subsequent to Uzbekistan becoming independent of the USSR in 1991. In 1999 the entire unit was dismantled and decontaminated, under OPCW supervision. We will need to hear from OPCW whether all the Novichok precursor chemicals [it is a “binary” agent, only becoming fully toxic when two or more less toxic precursors are mixed together] were fully accounted for and safely disposed of. It would also be necessary for those precursors to be stable and effective over 26 years. But the key point is that both sites were at all times under tight Soviet/Russian military control. So any possible leak is a Russian government responsibility.

Dr Vil Mirzayanov, who revealed Novichok’s existence in the 1990s believes that the Salisbury and Amesbury cases must have been different batch of the nerve agent as it would have decomposed over the intervening months, especially in damp conditions. However, Andrea Sella, professor of inorganic chemistry at University College London, said: ‘They [Novichok nerve agents] don’t evaporate, they don’t break up in water. The last four months have been dry so I suspect they can be there for quite a long time.’ A government source said: ‘Novichok doesn’t evaporate.
